CHAPTER 13: THE UNION OF KINGDOMS

February 15, 1431
Toledo, Kingdom of Castile

Dawn of a Sacred Day

The first light of dawn crept through the narrow windows of the Royal Alcázar, casting pale bands of gold across the stone floors. Toledo stirred to life with unusual energy—the city had been awake half the night, it seemed, with anticipation and preparation. Every street, every plaza, every inn overflowed with nobility from across Castile, their banners hanging from balconies, their guards filling the squares. The city had not seen such a gathering in living memory.

In the royal chambers, the morning began before sunrise. The soft knock at the door came precisely at the appointed hour—servants entering with hushed reverence, carrying water heated for washing, fresh linens, and the ceremonial garments prepared for the day. The room smelled of lavender and beeswax from the candles that had burned through the night in the small chapel adjacent to the bedchamber.

Through the window, Toledo spread below in the pre-dawn gloom—a sea of terracotta roofs, church spires piercing upward, the Tagus River curving around the city like a protective arm. Somewhere in those streets, the cathedral bells would soon begin their call to the most significant Mass the kingdom had witnessed in years.

The chief chamberlain, an elderly man named Don Rodrigo de Villalobos, supervised the preparations with military precision. Behind him, three younger servants waited with various elements of the ceremonial dress—but not the armor. That would come later, at the appointed moment.

"Your Majesty," Don Rodrigo said quietly, bowing. "The city awaits. Princess Isabel has been awake for two hours already—her Portuguese ladies report she has barely eaten, too nervous. Cardinal Capranica is at the cathedral, overseeing the final arrangements. The Guardian Company has been at vigil with the banner and relics since midnight." He paused. "It is time to begin preparations."

The morning routine would be extensive. First, the ritual cleansing and dressing in the white linen undergarments. Then the formal doublet and hose, embroidered with the royal arms. Only after the procession to the cathedral would come the moment all of Toledo waited to see—the donning of the white armor before the cathedral doors.

Outside, the city continued to wake. Market vendors hawked fresh bread and wine to the crowds already gathering along the processional route. Children darted between adults' legs, trying to secure the best viewing positions. Guards from a dozen noble houses stood at attention outside their lords' temporary residences. And in every church across Toledo, bells began their morning call—not in the usual pattern, but in a cascading celebration that rolled across the city like waves.

Don Rodrigo gestured to the servants, who approached with basin and cloth.

What does Juan do?

Small change in the program: I don my armour privately and ride in procession on my mount with all the banners flying through the streets. At the cathedral I dismount and take off my helmet and enter the cathedral with Isabel in my armour. Then we have tha mass and the wedding and then we go outside to the plaza where another blessing will take place so everyone can see us. During the mass, the banner and relics are revealed for the first time to the public. After the ceremony on the plaza, the banner is carried outside where it is being held at attention above the fifty crusaders. This is a call for more volunteers.


Then we do a tour around the city and in the evening we have a dinner with nobles where the taxation is officially announced. I ready the realm for war.


I get ready by donning my armour at the palace.


Remember that My outfit is plain all-white without a red cross or any emblem. My banners likewise are just plain while but with texture accents at most, like the banner which is also white with no emblem or sign.

February 15, 1431 - Dawn
Royal Alcázar, Toledo

The Armoring

Don Rodrigo nodded at Juan's instruction and immediately dispatched servants. "Summon Master Gonzalo at once. And clear the great hall—His Majesty will arm there, not in the cathedral plaza."

Within minutes, the great hall had been transformed into an armory. Servants carried in the pieces with reverence—the polished Milan plate gleaming even in the dim morning light, each piece wrapped in linen to prevent scratching during transport. Master Gonzalo himself arrived, slightly breathless, his apprentices behind him carrying the specialized padding and additional equipment.

"Your Majesty," the master armorer bowed deeply. "The privilege of arming you on this day..." He gestured to his apprentices, who began laying out the pieces in precise order on a long table draped in white cloth.

The process was methodical, almost ritual. First came the arming doublet—quilted linen designed to cushion the armor's weight and absorb the shock of any blows. Then the leg harness: greaves strapped over the shins, poleyns protecting the knees, cuisses buckled around the thighs. Each piece was masterwork—smooth, articulated, fitted so perfectly that movement felt almost natural despite the weight.

Álvaro entered quietly, watching the process with an expression that mixed pride and something deeper—perhaps the weight of what this day meant. He said nothing, simply took a position near the window where he could observe without interfering.

The breastplate came next, the most magnificent piece. Master Gonzalo and two apprentices lifted it carefully, settling it onto Juan's shoulders. The armorer's fingers moved with practiced expertise, threading leather straps through buckles, testing the fit, ensuring every articulation point allowed full range of motion. The backplate followed, enclosing the torso in a shell of gleaming steel.

"Raise your arms, Your Majesty," Master Gonzalo murmured, testing the shoulder articulation. "Now forward, as if drawing a sword. Good. The fit is perfect."

The arm harness came piece by piece—vambraces on the forearms, couters at the elbows, rerebrace on the upper arms. Each piece connected to the next with precision-engineered sliding rivets that allowed the arm to bend, extend, twist naturally. Gauntlets followed, the fingers articulated so delicately that Juan could still grip effectively despite the steel encasing his hands.

The gorget was placed last among the body pieces—a collar of steel that protected the throat while allowing the head to turn. Master Gonzalo stepped back, examining his work critically, then nodded in satisfaction.

"The helm, if Your Majesty pleases."

An apprentice brought forward the great bascinet with its distinctive white plume. Not the cheap-dyed horsehair plumes of common knights, but something finer—white egret feathers, perhaps, long and flowing. The helmet was fitted with careful attention, the chin strap secured, the visor tested to ensure it raised and lowered smoothly.

Finally, over all of it, the white surcoat—pure white linen without device or emblem, falling to mid-thigh. The fabric had been specially treated to hold its shape while still allowing the armor's lines to show through.

The effect, as Master Gonzalo had predicted weeks before, was extraordinary.

Álvaro spoke for the first time, his voice quiet. "You look like the Archangel Michael himself, Your Majesty. God help any man who sees this armor on a battlefield and doesn't feel his courage falter."

Master Gonzalo bowed deeply. "The greatest work of my life, Your Majesty. May it serve you well in God's war."

Outside, the sounds of gathering had intensified. Horses stamping, guards calling orders, the distant roar of crowds already lining the processional route. Don Rodrigo appeared at the doorway.

"Your Majesty, the company is assembled. Your horse is ready—the white destrier, caparisoned as you ordered. The Guardian Company waits with the banner and relics, prepared to ride in escort. Princess Isabel's procession is forming separately at the Archbishop's palace—she will meet you at the cathedral. The route is lined five deep in places. They've been waiting since before dawn."

He paused, something like awe in his usually formal voice. "Sire, Toledo has never seen anything like this. When you ride through those streets..." He shook his head, unable to find words.

Fray Hernando entered then, his Franciscan robes somehow looking more dignified than usual. He carried a small vessel of holy water. "Your Majesty, if I may—a blessing before you ride forth."

The friar's prayer was brief but fervent, calling down divine protection and favor, sanctifying the armor as an instrument of holy purpose. When he finished, he made the sign of the cross over Juan's breastplate with his thumb.

"You ride to your wedding, Your Majesty, but also to the beginning of God's work. May He grant you strength for both."

In the courtyard, Juan's destrier waited—a massive white warhorse, seventeen hands high, its coat gleaming from hours of grooming. The caparison that covered it was pure white linen, falling almost to its hooves, without device or heraldry. The saddle beneath was the finest leather, padded for comfort during the long procession, but military in design—this was a warhorse, not a palfrey.

The Guardian Company was mounted and ready—fifty crusaders on horseback, their white tabards brilliant in the growing morning light, red crosses stark against the fabric. They held themselves with absolute discipline, lances upright, faces solemn. At their center, borne by four of their number on a specially constructed frame, was the banner itself—white silk rippling slightly in the morning breeze, the texture of its weave catching the light. No devices, no heraldry, just pure white. Beside the banner rode two crusaders carrying the reliquaries containing the fragments of the True Cross and Saint James's bone, each encased in gold and silver that glinted like fire.

Behind them, the royal household guard—thirty knights in polished armor, the royal standard of Castile (quarterly castles and lions) borne among them to represent the crown's temporal authority alongside the crusade's spiritual purity.

The city beyond the palace gates roared with anticipation.

Don Rodrigo approached, holding the reins of the destrier. "Your Majesty, all is ready. The route will take you down from the Alcázar through the Plaza de Zocodover, along the Calle del Comercio through the heart of the city, and up to the cathedral plaza. Perhaps thirty minutes if we maintain processional pace. The crowds..." He shook his head again. "You will see, Your Majesty."

Álvaro mounted his own horse—a black destrier nearly as impressive as Juan's own, though caparisoned in the blue and gold of his house. He positioned himself at Juan's right hand, where the Constable of Castile belonged.

The gates of the Alcázar stood open. Beyond them, Toledo waited.

What does Juan do?

I mount my horse and make sure the banners attached to my saddle are in place correctly. eight feet high flying white banners will make me look like a flying angel. When I am mounted, I ride a chort circle to test if the banners are flowing freely.

The Mounting

A mounting block had been positioned beside the destrier—even for an experienced rider, mounting in full plate armor required assistance. Two grooms steadied the horse while Juan placed his gauntleted hand on the saddle's high cantle. The weight of the armor was substantial, but the perfectly balanced distribution and Master Gonzalo's precise fitting allowed fluid movement. With one smooth motion, Juan swung up into the saddle, settling into position with the practiced ease of a knight who'd been riding since childhood.

The destrier shifted slightly under the added weight, but held steady—a true warhorse, trained to bear both armored rider and the chaos of battle without flinching.

Master Gonzalo's apprentices immediately moved forward with the banner poles. There were two of them, designed to attach to special reinforced brackets welded to the saddle's frame on either side, just behind Juan's legs. Each pole was perhaps nine feet in total length—the first foot secured in the bracket, leaving eight feet rising above.

The white silk banners attached to these poles were long and narrow, perhaps two feet wide and six feet long, designed to stream backward as the horse moved. The fabric was finest silk, light enough to catch even gentle air movement, but treated to hold its shape and prevent tangling. No devices, no emblems—just pure white with subtle texture woven into the fabric that caught light in shifting patterns.

The apprentices worked carefully, sliding the first pole into its bracket with a solid click as it locked into place. Then the second on the opposite side. The poles rose high above Juan's head, the banners hanging almost still in the relatively calm morning air of the courtyard.

"Test the balance, Your Majesty," Master Gonzalo advised. "The poles are counterweighted, but movement will tell you if anything needs adjustment."

Juan gathered the reins, feeling the leather through his articulated gauntlets. The destrier responded immediately to the subtle pressure of his knees—well-trained, responsive despite the unusual cargo it now bore. He urged the horse forward into a slow walk, then turned it in a wide circle around the courtyard.

The effect was immediate and spectacular.

As the horse moved, even at a walk, the banners caught the air and began to stream backward. The higher pace increased the effect—the white silk unfurling fully, flowing behind like wings of white fire. The texture in the fabric created shifting patterns of light and shadow as it rippled, making the banners seem almost alive, almost luminous.

Juan urged the destrier to a slow trot, completing another circle. The banners now fully extended, streaming eight feet behind him at shoulder height, the white silk brilliant in the morning sun that had begun to break over Toledo's walls. The poles held perfectly steady in their brackets, the engineering sound. The overall silhouette was exactly as Master Gonzalo had envisioned—a mounted knight in pure white armor, white plumes on his helm, white surcoat, white banners flowing like angel's wings, on a white destrier.

Álvaro's jaw had literally dropped. "Madre de Dios," he breathed. "Your Majesty... when the people see this..."

Fray Hernando had tears in his eyes. "Saint Michael," he whispered. "The Archangel himself descending to make war on the infidel."

Even the hardened household guards were staring, their usual professional composure broken. One crossed himself rapidly. Another muttered a prayer under his breath.

The Guardian Company crusaders sat straighter in their saddles, their faces shining with something beyond mere loyalty—reverence, perhaps, or the kind of faith that moves mountains. They had pledged their lives to this crusade, and now they could see its living symbol before them.

Master Gonzalo approached, his face showing pride mixed with something deeper. "Perfect, Your Majesty. The balance holds, the brackets are secure, the silk flows freely. You could ride like this into battle itself without hindrance." He stepped back, bowing deeply. "God has granted me the privilege of creating something... something that will be remembered long after I am dust."

Don Rodrigo had to clear his throat twice before he could speak. "Your Majesty, the city awaits. When you ride through those gates..." He shook his head, seemingly unable to articulate what he felt.

Beyond the palace gates, the roar of the crowd had intensified—they couldn't see into the courtyard yet, but word was spreading somehow through that mysterious osmosis by which crowds sense great events. The sound was building, a low thunder of thousands of voices in anticipation.

The Guardian Company banner-bearers adjusted their formation, ready to precede Juan. The four carrying the blessed banner on its frame moved to the fore. The two bearing the reliquaries positioned themselves on either side. The remaining crusaders formed an honor guard, lances at precisely the same angle, their discipline absolute.

Álvaro brought his black destrier alongside Juan's white one. His voice was quiet but intense. "Your Majesty, when you ride through those streets, you will inspire such faith, such devotion... Men will fight for you. Men will die for you. And they will do it with joy in their hearts, believing they serve God's own champion."

He paused, his usual political calculation giving way to genuine emotion. "I have served your father and now you. I have seen power wielded in many forms. But this... this is something different. This is the power of faith made visible. Use it well, Your Majesty. Use it to unite this kingdom as it has never been united before."

The destrier stamped, eager to move. The banners rippled with the slight motion, catching light and seeming to glow.

The gates of the Alcázar stood open. Beyond them, the streets of Toledo surged with humanity. The processional route awaited—a path through the heart of the greatest city in Castile, lined with every noble house, every guild, every religious order, and tens of thousands of common people who had come from across the kingdom to witness this moment.

At the cathedral, Princess Isabel waited, probably terrified, surrounded by her Portuguese ladies and the Archbishop's household. Cardinal Capranica prepared the High Mass that would join two kingdoms and launch a holy war.

Everything was ready.

What does Juan do?

The Ride of Angels

"GUARDIANS! WE RIDE!"

The command cut through the morning air like a sword stroke. The fifty crusaders responded as one, their voices unified in a thunderous cry: "FOR CHRIST AND CASTILE!"

The Guardian Company surged forward. The four bearing the great white banner on its frame moved first, the silk rippling as they passed through the Alcázar gates. The two with the golden and silver reliquaries followed, the morning sun catching the precious metals and sending shafts of light dancing across the courtyard stones. Then the remaining crusaders, lances upright, white tabards brilliant, red crosses blazing.

Juan urged his destrier forward. The warhorse responded eagerly, powerful muscles gathering beneath white caparison. As they passed through the gates, the banners attached to his saddle caught the breeze and streamed backward—eight feet of pure white silk flowing like wings of fire.

And then they emerged into the streets of Toledo.

The sound hit like a physical force.

The roar of the crowd was deafening—a wall of noise that seemed to shake the very stones of the ancient city. Thousands upon thousands of voices raised in a cry that was part cheer, part prayer, part something beyond words. The street leading down from the Alcázar was packed on both sides, people pressed five and six deep behind wooden barriers manned by city guards who struggled to hold the lines.

The moment the white-armored figure on the white horse appeared with those impossible flowing banners, the noise redoubled. Women screamed. Men shouted themselves hoarse. Children were lifted onto shoulders to see better. Some people fell to their knees, crossing themselves frantically. Others simply stared, mouths open, tears streaming down their faces.

"AN ANGEL! AN ANGEL OF GOD!"

The cry came from somewhere in the crowd and spread like wildfire. Within seconds, dozens were shouting it, then hundreds. "SAINT MICHAEL! SAINT MICHAEL RIDES TO WAR!"

The Guardian Company processed ahead, maintaining perfect discipline despite the chaos around them. The blessed banner rippled and caught light, seeming almost to glow in the morning sun. The reliquaries gleamed like stars. The crusaders sat their horses with absolute stillness, but many had tears streaming down their faces beneath their helms, moved beyond words by the faith they witnessed.

Juan rode through it all in full plate, his white plumes streaming, his banners flowing behind him like living things. The destrier's hooves rang on the cobblestones—a rhythmic counterpoint to the chaos of adoration around them. Every step forward seemed to intensify the crowd's fervor.

At the Plaza de Zocodover, the city's great central square, the scene became even more overwhelming. The plaza was absolutely packed—easily three thousand people crammed into a space meant for market stalls and commerce. When the procession entered, a sound rose up that was unlike anything human—a collective gasp of thousands drawing breath at once, followed by a roar that seemed to come from the earth itself.

The great noble houses had erected viewing stands along the plaza's edges. There sat the highest nobility of Castile—grandees in their finest clothing, their ladies in silk and jewels, their household knights in polished armor. But even they were standing now, straining to see, their carefully maintained dignity forgotten in the face of what they witnessed.

Don Íñigo López de Mendoza the Elder stood in his house's stand, his son Pedro beside him. The young heir had tears on his face, his hand pressed to his heart where his crusader's oath resided. The old lord simply nodded slowly, as if something he'd long suspected had been confirmed.

Admiral Fadrique Enríquez stood with his hands gripping the railing of his viewing stand, his knuckles white. His naval expertise meant nothing in this moment—he was seeing the power of faith made manifest, and it left him shaken.

The Archbishop of Toledo's clergy had assembled near their stand, their ceremonial robes brilliant in the sun. They began chanting—not the planned processional hymn, but spontaneously breaking into the Te Deum. "We praise Thee, O God, we acknowledge Thee to be the Lord..." The Latin rose above the crowd's noise, adding structure and sanctity to the chaos.

Down the Calle del Comercio, Toledo's main commercial street, the scene repeated and intensified. Merchants had closed their shops to watch. Craftsmen left their workshops. Every window, every balcony, every rooftop was packed with people. Banners hung from buildings—some showing noble heraldry, others hastily sewn white cloth in imitation of the crusade's banner.

At one corner, a group of monks from the Monastery of San Juan de los Reyes had formed a procession of their own, bearing crosses and singing hymns. When Juan's procession passed, they fell in behind, adding their voices to the growing train of followers. City guards gave up trying to stop people from joining—the crowd simply flowed around obstacles like water.

A woman broke through the barriers—elderly, dressed in black widow's weeds. She fell to her knees in the street before the procession, hands raised in supplication. "FOR MY SON!" she screamed. "WHO FELL AT ANTEQUERA! FINISH THE WORK! FINISH IT!"

One of the Guardian Company crusaders broke formation slightly, reaching down as he passed to touch her outstretched hand—a moment of connection between the sacred mission and the human cost it sought to redeem. City guards gently pulled the woman back to safety, but she continued shouting blessings through her tears.

The procession climbed now, heading up toward the cathedral district where Toledo's greatest churches crowned the highest ground. The streets narrowed here, the buildings pressing closer, the crowd's noise echoing off stone walls until it became a physical vibration in the air.

Religious orders lined the route in this section—Franciscans in their brown robes, Dominicans in black and white, Benedictines, Cistercians, every order represented. They knelt as the banner passed, their heads bowed in reverence for the relics it bore. Some reached out to touch the hooves of the Guardian Company's horses, seeking blessing by proximity to sacred things.

Ahead, the Cathedral of Toledo rose into view—the greatest church in Castile, its Gothic towers piercing the sky like prayers made stone. The plaza before it was even more packed than Zocodover had been, if that were possible. Every inch of space held humanity—nobles in their designated areas, common people filling every other gap, clergy in procession, guards struggling to maintain order.

At the cathedral steps, a small cleared area had been maintained by a double line of guards. There, barely visible through the crowd, stood a cluster of Portuguese ladies in their distinctive court dress, and among them, a small figure in white—Princess Isabel, waiting for her husband-to-be.

The procession entered the cathedral plaza and the noise somehow became even more intense. People climbed onto the statues that decorated the plaza. Young men hung from the iron railings of the cathedral's outer wall. Every vantage point held spectators. The city watch had given up maintaining order and simply worked to prevent people from being crushed.

As Juan approached the cleared space before the cathedral steps, the Guardian Company divided smoothly—twenty-five moving to each side, creating an aisle of white-tabarded crusaders. The four bearing the great banner on its frame continued forward until they reached the cathedral steps, then halted, the white silk hanging magnificently against the gothic stone.

The two bearing the reliquaries positioned themselves on either side of the banner, the gold and silver gleaming in the sun. The remaining crusaders formed up in perfect ranks, lances now held at identical angles, their discipline absolute despite the chaos around them.

Álvaro remained at Juan's side as they rode through this honor guard toward the cathedral steps. The Constable's face showed something beyond his usual political calculation—genuine awe, perhaps, or the recognition that he was witnessing history being made.

The white destrier came to a halt at the base of the cathedral steps, its hooves ringing one final time on the ancient stones. The banners attached to Juan's saddle continued to stream in the breeze, white silk flowing, catching light, seeming almost to dance.

The plaza fell into a sudden, shocked silence—thousands of people somehow managing to quiet themselves all at once, as if by common instinct they recognized that a sacred moment had arrived.

In that silence, the cathedral bells began to ring—not the usual pattern, but a cascading celebration that rolled across Toledo and beyond, carrying the news to every corner of the kingdom.

King Juan II had arrived for his wedding.

What does Juan do?

I take off my helmet and take it under my shoulder and adress the crowd.


I am Juan, king of Castille. Today, I will marry Isabel of Portugal. Today as I make my wedding vows, I also reaffirm another vow made months ago when I met the pope in Rome when I promised him that one thing on the mind of every Christian Castillian from the moment we can walk. I talk of course of the reconquista!


We will march for Grenada. Let the sultan tremble in fear for the sons of christ, for we are coming for him and the vile Moors who have so violently been raiding and enslaving us christians for so long. We will finish it, I promise you this!


I ask you all to pray for one another, pray for me, and if God is willing, we will succeed.


I dismount, give my helmet to an attendant and walk to Isabel.

The Oath Before the People

Juan reached up with both gauntleted hands and grasped his bascinet. The articulated finger plates of his gauntlets moved smoothly as he lifted the helm free. The white plume caught the breeze as he brought the helmet down to tuck under his left arm, the practiced motion of a knight who'd done this a thousand times.

His face was revealed—young, serious, sweat-dampened from the heat of the enclosed helm but composed. At eighteen, he looked both impossibly young for the armor he wore and somehow exactly right for it. His dark hair was plastered to his head, his eyes bright with intensity as he looked out across the sea of faces.

The plaza held its breath.

Juan's voice rang out across the cathedral plaza, trained by years of court ceremony to project clearly without shouting:

"I am Juan, King of Castile!"

The crowd erupted briefly, then fell silent again, desperate to hear every word.

"Today, I will marry Isabel of Portugal. Today, as I make my wedding vows, I also reaffirm another vow made months ago when I met the Pope in Rome, when I promised him that one thing on the mind of every Christian Castilian from the moment we can walk. I talk of course of the Reconquista!"

The word sent a shockwave through the plaza. Men shouted. Women wept. The sound built like thunder.

"We will march for Granada! Let the sultan tremble in fear for the sons of Christ, for we are coming for him and the vile Moors who have so violently been raiding and enslaving us Christians for so long. We will finish it, I promise you this!"

The roar was deafening now—a sound of rage and joy and religious fervor mixed into something primal. Fists raised toward heaven. Swords were drawn and held high by knights in the crowd. The elderly widow who had broken through earlier was screaming blessings, her voice lost in the chaos but her meaning clear.

"I ask you all to pray for one another, pray for me, and if God is willing, we will succeed!"

"WE WILL! WE WILL!" The cry came from a thousand throats at once. "FOR CASTILE! FOR CHRIST! FOR JUAN!"

The Guardian Company crusaders had tears streaming down their faces beneath their helms. Some were openly weeping, their lances wavering slightly as emotion overwhelmed discipline. Fray Hernando stood among them with his hands raised in benediction, his lips moving in constant prayer.

In the noble viewing areas, the great houses were on their feet, shouting their approval. Don Íñigo López de Mendoza was bellowing support, his dignity completely abandoned. Admiral Enríquez had drawn his sword and held it high. Even the most cautious grandees—men who'd spent careers calculating political advantage—were caught up in the moment, their faces shining with something beyond mere calculation.

The Archbishop of Toledo stood on the cathedral steps, his ceremonial robes brilliant in the sun, his crosier raised high. Behind him, Cardinal Capranica had emerged from the cathedral's interior, drawn by the noise. The papal legate's usually stern face showed something like wonder as he witnessed the fervor of this crowd.

Juan swung down from the destrier in a smooth motion despite the plate armor—the perfectly fitted harness allowing movement that lesser work would have restricted. An attendant rushed forward to take his helmet, handling it with reverence as if it were a holy relic itself. Another attendant moved to the destrier's head, holding the reins of the great warhorse.

The white banners attached to the saddle continued to stream in the breeze, even with the horse standing still. The effect was hypnotic—white silk flowing, catching light, seeming alive.

Juan walked forward through the honor guard of crusaders, his armored feet ringing on the stones. The white surcoat flowed around him with each step. The crowd's noise had become a constant roar, individual words lost in the collective voice of thousands.

Her dark hair was braided and coiled, partially covered by a delicate white veil held in place by a simple golden circlet. She looked very small, very young, very Portuguese among her ladies.

The Guardian Company held their positions, the blessed banner rippling above them. The white silk banners on Juan's destrier flowed in the breeze behind him like ghostly wings.

Isabel's eyes met Juan's. In that moment, surrounded by thousands, they were somehow alone—two young people about to bind their lives together for purposes far larger than themselves.

The Tender Moment

Juan reached out with his right gauntlet, the articulated steel fingers somehow managing gentleness as he took Isabel's small hand in his. The contrast was stark—delicate pale skin against polished Milan plate, fragility against strength, Portugal against Castile.

He lifted her hand carefully, bowing his head to press his lips against her knuckles through the gap in his armor where the gauntlet met the vambrace. The gesture was courtly, proper, but also genuinely tender—a moment of human connection in the midst of overwhelming spectacle.

His lips moved close to her hand: "It will be alright."

Whether she heard the actual words over the crowd's roar was uncertain, but she felt them—felt the intention, the reassurance. Her terrified expression softened slightly. Her fingers, which had been rigid with tension, relaxed just a fraction in his steel grip. She nodded, barely perceptibly, and managed the ghost of a smile.

"I trust you," she mouthed back, though the words were lost to the noise.

Dona Beatriz, standing just behind Isabel, had tears streaming down her face—whether from the overwhelming spectacle or from seeing her princess find courage in this moment, it was impossible to say. The other Portuguese ladies were equally moved, their faces showing pride in their princess's composure.

The Archbishop gestured toward the cathedral's great doors, which stood open to reveal the vast interior beyond. Cardinal Capranica moved to join him, the two most senior churchmen in Castile prepared to lead the procession inside.

Juan offered his armored arm to Isabel. She placed her hand delicately on his vambrace, her fingers looking impossibly small against the steel. Together, they turned toward the cathedral.

The crowd's roar somehow intensified—if such a thing were possible—as the people realized the procession was moving inside. Those who had positions in the cathedral itself began pressing forward. The city guards struggled to maintain the cleared paths.

Entering the Cathedral

The Guardian Company reformed, the four bearing the great banner on its frame leading the way. They ascended the cathedral steps slowly, reverently, the white silk rippling with their movement. The two crusaders bearing the golden and silver reliquaries followed, holding the precious containers high for all to see. The remaining crusaders fell in behind, their discipline absolute.

Juan and Isabel followed, climbing the steps together. With each step, the crowd's noise faded slightly as the cathedral's massive stone walls began to muffle it. The transition from brilliant morning sunlight to the cathedral's dimmer interior made everyone blink, eyes adjusting.

The Cathedral of Toledo was one of Christendom's grandest churches—a Gothic masterpiece of soaring vaults, pointed arches, and stained glass that turned sunlight into rivers of colored fire. The nave stretched impossibly long, lined with massive columns that rose like ancient trees toward the vaulted ceiling far overhead. The air smelled of incense, old stone, beeswax from thousands of candles, and the subtle mustiness of centuries.

But today, every available space was packed with humanity.

The nave was filled with Toledo's elite—great nobles, their ladies, senior clergy, representatives of religious orders, masters of the military orders, wealthy merchants who'd paid dearly for positions, foreign ambassadors, and anyone else who'd had sufficient status or connections to gain entry. Perhaps two thousand people stood in the great church, and every eye turned toward the procession as it entered.

The response was immediate. Those nearest the door began to kneel—first dozens, then hundreds, then the entire congregation like a wave rolling through the nave. The sound was extraordinary—two thousand people lowering themselves to the stone floor simultaneously, the rustle of fabric, the clink of metal, the scrape of knees on stone.

They weren't kneeling for the king. They were kneeling for what he represented—for the banner, the relics, the sacred mission he embodied.

The Guardian Company processed down the central aisle toward the high altar. The banner swayed gently with their movement, white silk glowing in the dim light. The reliquaries caught candlelight and threw it back in golden and silver flashes. Behind them, Juan and Isabel walked together—he in his white armor, she in her white gown, an image of sacred union before a single vow had been spoken.

The cathedral's choir had begun singing—not the planned processional hymn, but something spontaneous, a soaring Latin chant that seemed to come from heaven itself. The acoustics of the great church carried the sound, amplifying it, making it seem as if angels sang from the vaulted ceiling.

As they processed deeper into the cathedral, Juan became increasingly aware of the armor's weight. Standing in plate harness was manageable for short periods, but a Full High Mass with coronation would last three hours or more. His legs would tire. His back would ache. The steel would seem to grow heavier with each passing minute. Knights trained for this—the ability to remain armored and alert for extended periods—but it was never comfortable.

The high altar rose before them, a masterwork of gilded wood and precious metals, decorated with centuries of accumulated treasures. Behind it, the great reredos—the ornate carved screen that rose three stories high—was a riot of biblical scenes and saints picked out in gold and vibrant colors. Hundreds of candles burned before it, their flames dancing in some unfelt draft.

To the left of the altar, a special area had been prepared with two ornate chairs—thrones, really—where Juan and Isabel would sit during the lengthy Mass. To the right, a raised platform had been constructed, currently covered with white silk cloth. This, clearly, was where the banner and relics would be displayed for the unveiling.

The Archbishop and Cardinal Capranica ascended to the altar, turning to face the congregation. The Guardian Company divided, the banner-bearers moving to the right side platform, the reliquary-bearers beside them. The remaining crusaders formed up in the choir stalls, filling the carved wooden seats usually reserved for the cathedral's clergy. Their white tabards blazed against the dark oak.

The congregation remained kneeling, heads bowed, as Juan and Isabel reached the altar steps.

Cardinal Capranica raised his hands, and the choir fell silent. In the sudden quiet, the legate's voice rang clear—practiced at projecting in large spaces, trained in the rhetorical arts of Rome.

"In nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti."

"Amen." Two thousand voices in perfect unison.

"Beloved of Christ, we are gathered in this holy place on this most sacred of days, to witness the union of two kingdoms, two souls, and two purposes in the sight of Almighty God..."

The Mass had begun. Juan felt Isabel's hand tighten slightly on his arm—nerves, excitement, fear, faith, all mixed together. He tried to project calm through his presence, his steadiness.

The Archbishop gestured for them to be seated in the throne-chairs. Juan moved carefully, the armor requiring deliberate movement to sit without tangling. The chair had been specially prepared—padded more than usual, the back angled to support an armored figure. Even so, sitting in plate harness meant sitting upright, back straight, no slouching. The weight settled onto his hips and spine.

Three hours. Minimum.

He caught Álvaro's eye where the Constable stood among the front rank of nobles. The older man gave him an almost imperceptible nod—encouragement, solidarity, recognition of what this physical ordeal would demand.

Isabel settled into her chair with considerably more grace, her ladies arranging her train around her. She glanced sideways at Juan, and despite her nervousness, there was something almost like amusement in her eyes—as if she recognized the absurdity of him sitting through a three-hour Mass in full plate armor and admired the commitment it represented.

Cardinal Capranica continued the liturgy, his Latin perfect, his voice carrying to every corner of the great church. The congregation responded at the appropriate moments, their voices rising and falling like waves.

The banner stood on its platform, still covered, awaiting its moment of revelation.

The Mass of Union

The overwhelming response outside had set the tone—this was no mere royal wedding, but a sacred moment that had captured the kingdom's imagination. Even inside the cathedral, the energy was palpable. The two thousand nobles, clergy, and privileged witnesses packed into the nave radiated an intensity that was unusual even for the religiously fervent society of 15th-century Castile.

Juan settled into the throne-chair as best he could. The armor's weight distributed differently when sitting—pressure on the hips, the lower back, the tops of the thighs where the cuisses rested. He shifted slightly, testing which position was least uncomfortable. The padding helped, but there was no escaping the fundamental reality: he would be encased in fifty pounds of steel for at least three hours.

He focused on technique—the methods Rodrigo and the other veterans had taught him. Don't lock the muscles. Shift weight subtly every few minutes. Engage different muscle groups. Breathe deeply and regularly. Think of it as endurance training rather than torture.

Isabel sat beside him, her posture perfect in the way of noblewomen trained from childhood. Her hands were folded in her lap, her face composed, but Juan could see the tension in her shoulders, the way she occasionally took a too-deep breath to calm herself.

He reached over and took her hand.

She startled slightly at the touch of the steel gauntlet, then her fingers curled around his, holding tight. She turned to look at him, and something passed between them—solidarity in facing this ordeal together, perhaps, or simply the comfort of not being alone in front of thousands.

Cardinal Capranica's voice rolled through the cathedral in sonorous Latin, beginning the liturgy of the Mass. The Kyrie Eleison—"Lord have mercy, Christ have mercy, Lord have mercy." The congregation's responses echoed from the stone walls, creating a sound that seemed to come from everywhere and nowhere.

The Archbishop of Toledo stood beside Capranica, occasionally taking portions of the liturgy, the two prelates working in practiced harmony. Incense rose from the thurible swung by acolytes, sweet smoke curling upward toward the vaulted ceiling.

Juan shifted his weight again—left hip to right hip, subtle enough that most wouldn't notice. The armor's articulation points at the waist allowed minimal movement. He engaged his core muscles, then relaxed them, then engaged again. Already, fifteen minutes in, he could feel the beginning of fatigue.

Isabel's thumb moved against his gauntlet in small circles—a nervous gesture, or perhaps deliberate comfort-seeking. He squeezed her hand gently in response.

The Gloria began—"Gloria in excelsis Deo"—the cathedral choir joining the congregation in the great hymn of praise. The music was magnificent, voices trained for decades blending with the untrained enthusiasm of the noble congregation. The acoustics transformed it into something transcendent.

Twenty-five minutes. Juan's lower back was beginning to ache. He straightened his spine, engaging different muscles, giving the fatigued ones brief respite. Breathe. Shift. Endure.

The readings began—Old Testament, Psalms, Epistle, each proclaimed from the great lectern by different clergy. Juan found himself actually listening, using the content to distract from discomfort. The selected readings emphasized faithfulness, covenant, divine blessing on righteous causes. Clearly chosen specifically for this occasion.

Isabel's hand remained in his throughout. Occasionally she would glance at him, checking on him perhaps, or seeking reassurance herself. Each time their eyes met, he tried to project calm confidence, and each time she seemed to draw strength from it.

Forty minutes. The Gospel reading—Matthew's account of the wedding at Cana, where Christ turned water to wine. Cardinal Capranica read it himself, his voice giving dramatic weight to each verse. The symbolism was heavy-handed but effective: divine blessing on marriage, miraculous transformation, faith rewarded.

Juan shifted again. Right hip to left. The breastplate's lower edge pressed against the top of his cuisses in this position. He adjusted the angle of his torso slightly. Better. For now.

The homily began. Capranica was a skilled orator, trained in Rome's rhetorical traditions. He wove together themes of marriage, crusade, divine purpose, and royal duty with practiced eloquence. He spoke of how this union joined Portugal and Castile in common cause, how Princess Isabel's faithfulness mirrored the faith required of all crusaders, how King Juan embodied both martial prowess and pious devotion.

The homily stretched to twenty minutes—long by some standards, brief by Capranica's. The legate was showing restraint, perhaps aware that even the most devout congregation had limits.

An hour and ten minutes. Juan's thighs were burning now, the muscles trembling slightly with fatigue. He locked his knees briefly to transfer some weight, then quickly unlocked them—dangerous to keep knees locked too long in armor. Could pass out. He'd seen it happen to knights at tournaments.

Isabel seemed to sense his discomfort. She leaned slightly toward him, whispering so quietly only he could hear: "You can do this."

He squeezed her hand in thanks.

The Creed began—the entire congregation reciting the Nicene Creed in unison. "Credo in unum Deum, Patrem omnipotentem..." The words washed over Juan, familiar from countless Masses, the rhythm almost meditative. He used the moment to shift again, engaging his left glutes, releasing his right, then reversing.

One hour and twenty-five minutes.

Then Cardinal Capranica raised his hands for silence. The choir ceased. The congregation stilled. Every eye turned to the altar.

"Before we proceed to the sacrament of marriage," the legate's voice rang clear, "we shall witness the unveiling of the sacred instruments of this holy crusade, blessed by His Holiness Pope Martin V, carried by this faithful king from Rome itself."

A murmur rippled through the cathedral—anticipation, excitement, religious fervor barely contained.

Four Guardian Company crusaders moved to the platform where the banner stood, still covered in white silk. Two more positioned themselves by the reliquaries. Fray Hernando stood nearby, his hands raised in prayer.

The moment stretched. Two thousand people holding their breath.

The crusaders grasped the covering and, with perfect synchronization, pulled it away.

The banner was revealed.

Pure white silk, eight feet tall, suspended from a horizontal crossbar on a pole that would make it ten feet total when carried. No devices, no heraldry, no emblems—just white fabric with subtle textures woven in that caught the candlelight and seemed to make it glow from within. Simple. Powerful. Holy.

But it was the reliquaries mounted on special brackets on either side of the banner's pole that drew gasps from the congregation. The golden reliquary containing the fragment of the True Cross gleamed like captured sunlight. The silver reliquary holding Saint James's bone shone like moonlight. Both were works of masterful craftsmanship, encrusted with gems, clearly visible even from the back of the cathedral.

The response was immediate. People fell to their knees throughout the nave—not all at once as before, but in waves as the significance hit them. Some wept openly. Others reached out as if they could touch the relics from their positions. Prayers rose up spontaneously from dozens of throats.

In the noble viewing areas, even the most jaded grandees looked moved. Don Íñigo López de Mendoza had removed his cap and bowed his head. Admiral Enríquez had a hand pressed to his heart. The Master of Santiago, Don Luis de Guzmán, stood with tears streaming into his beard.

Among the common observers in the rear sections, the reaction was even more pronounced. An elderly man collapsed, overcome. Women sobbed. Young men stared with expressions of awe and desperate desire—they wanted to serve under that banner, to touch those relics, to be part of this sacred mission.

Cardinal Capranica let the moment stretch, understanding the power of silence. Then, his voice thick with emotion: "Behold the banner of Christ's holy war. Behold the relics of our salvation. Blessed by the Vicar of Christ. Carried by the righteous. Wielded against the infidel."

He turned to Juan and Isabel. "And now, before these sacred witnesses, we shall join together these two souls in holy matrimony."

One hour and forty minutes into the Mass. Juan's entire body ached now, but the banner's unveiling had given him new energy—reminded him why he endured this, what purpose drove everything.

Isabel's hand trembled in his. Whether from religious awe or nervousness about the vows to come, he couldn't tell. Perhaps both.

The Archbishop gestured for them to rise and approach the altar. Juan stood carefully—the armor made quick movements dangerous, easy to lose balance. His legs screamed in protest, muscles cramped from the long sitting. He locked them straight for just a moment to stabilize, then forced them to work properly.

Isabel rose gracefully, her Portuguese ladies moving forward to arrange her train as she walked. Together, they stepped up to stand directly before the altar, Cardinal Capranica and the Archbishop flanking them.

Behind them, two thousand witnesses. Above them, the vaulted ceiling soaring to heaven. Before them, the altar and beyond it the magnificent reredos with its golden saints. To their right, the banner and relics, glowing in candlelight. To their left, the Guardian Company in their white tabards, every man standing at rigid attention.

Capranica opened the great marriage ritual book, its pages illuminated with gold leaf and brilliant pigments. He began the ancient liturgy, his Latin perfect, each word weighted with centuries of tradition.

"Nos convocati sumus in conspectu Dei..." We are gathered here in the sight of God...

The ritual proceeded through its established forms. Questions about consent, about freedom from impediment, about understanding of marriage's sacred nature. Isabel answered in a clear voice, her Portuguese-accented Latin perfectly understandable. Juan's responses rang through the cathedral in the trained voice of a king accustomed to being heard.

Then came the moment for the vows themselves. Capranica turned to Juan, the ritual book open before him.

"Juan, Rex Castellae, wilt thou have this woman to be thy wedded wife, to live together after God's ordinance in the holy estate of matrimony? Wilt thou love her, comfort her, honor and keep her, in sickness and in health, and forsaking all others, keep thee only unto her, so long as ye both shall live?"

He gestured, and more acolytes came forward bearing the crown of Castile—not Juan's personal crown worn for governance, but the great ceremonial crown used only for the most sacred occasions. It was a masterwork of gold and jewels, heavy with symbolism and precious metals.

"Kneel," the legate commanded.

Juan lowered himself carefully, the armor making the movement awkward. Getting down to both knees in plate harness required balance and control—one wrong shift and he'd topple. But he managed it, kneeling on the stone steps before the altar.

Isabel knelt beside him with considerably more grace, her ladies arranging her train around her.

The Archbishop of Toledo stepped forward now, joining Capranica for this portion. Together, the two most powerful churchmen in Castile stood over the kneeling couple, the great crown held between them.

Capranica's voice rose in the ancient coronation prayer: "Bless, we beseech Thee, O Lord, this crown, and so sanctify Thy servant Isabel who by our humble ministry is this day to be crowned Queen..."

The crown was placed on Isabel's head—not the full weight of a king's crown, but the lighter coronet of a queen consort, still substantial with its gold and gems. She kept her head perfectly straight, balancing the weight with the poise of someone who'd been trained for this since childhood.

The congregation erupted in applause—their new queen, crowned and consecrated.

The Archbishop raised his hands for silence, then intoned the blessing over both of them: "May the Lord bless you and keep you. May the Lord make His face to shine upon you and be gracious unto you. May the Lord lift up His countenance upon you and give you peace, both now and in the hour of your death and in the world to come. Amen."

"Amen," the cathedral responded.

"You may rise," Capranica said, and Juan could hear the faint amusement in the legate's voice—he knew full well how difficult rising in armor would be.

Juan managed it, using core strength and careful balance, getting one foot under him and pushing up smoothly. His legs protested, but held. He reached down to help Isabel, his bare hand taking hers, and together they rose to face the congregation.

King Juan II of Castile and Queen Isabel of Castile, crowned and wed.

The applause was deafening. Even the most dignified nobles were shouting approval. The Guardian Company crusaders were cheering, their voices raised in something between military salute and religious benediction.

But the Mass was not over. There were still the Eucharistic prayers, the consecration, communion, the final blessings. Another hour at least.

Capranica gestured them back to the throne-chairs. Juan moved carefully, his bare hand still holding Isabel's, his gauntlet dangling from its strap. They sat together, now husband and wife, to witness the remaining liturgy.

Isabel leaned close, whispering: "You were perfect."

Juan squeezed her hand, then managed to work his gauntlet back on one-handed—a skill every knight learned. The armor's weight seemed somehow more bearable now. Purpose renewed. The hardest part done.

The Mass continued. Two hours and fifteen minutes elapsed. Juan shifted, breathed, endured. Beside him, Isabel sat with the crown on her head, adjusting to its weight, her face showing concentration and growing confidence.

The consecration of the Eucharist. The prayers of the faithful. Communion distributed to the royal couple first, then to the front ranks of nobles, then working backward through the congregation. This alone took nearly thirty minutes—two thousand people receiving the host.

Two hours and fifty minutes. Juan's entire body was one long ache now, but he could see the end approaching. Final prayers. Final blessings.

At last, Cardinal Capranica raised his hands one final time: "Ite, missa est."

"Deo gratias." Thanks be to God. The response had never been more heartfelt.

"Go forth in peace, to love and serve the Lord. And may Almighty God bless you, the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit."

"Amen."

Three hours and five minutes. The Mass was complete.

The Guardian Company moved immediately, four crusaders lifting the banner on its frame, two taking the reliquaries. They processed toward the cathedral doors, the white silk catching the light streaming in from outside.

Juan stood—carefully, painfully—and offered his arm to Isabel. She rose, the crown balanced perfectly on her head now, and took his arm. Together, they followed the banner toward the doors and the plaza beyond, where thousands more waited to see them.

The procession reformed. Clergy, then the banner and relics, then Juan and Isabel, then the nobility in order of precedence. The cathedral doors stood open, brilliant sunlight streaming in, the roar of the crowd outside audible even through the thick stone walls.

They stepped through the doors onto the cathedral steps, and the noise hit like a physical force. The plaza was even more packed than before—if anything, more people had arrived during the three-hour Mass, cramming into every available space.

When the crowd saw them—saw Juan in his white armor with Isabel crowned beside him, saw the banner and relics raised high—the roar redoubled. This was what they'd been waiting for. The king and queen. The blessed banner. The sacred cause made visible.

A platform had been erected on the cathedral steps for this moment—a raised area where they could be seen by the maximum number of people. Archbishop and Cardinal ascended with them, prepared to give a final blessing visible to all.

A Moment of Humanity

As they walked toward the platform, Juan leaned down close to Isabel's ear, his voice low enough that only she could hear beneath the crowd's roar:

"I am commissioning a painting of our wedding. Wearing my armor during that Mass was hell. I sure hope it was worth it. I can't wait to get out of this hot plate."

Isabel's response was immediate—a sudden, startled laugh that she barely managed to suppress into a very unqueenly snort. Her hand flew to her mouth, her eyes dancing with surprised delight. The crown wobbled slightly on her head.

She turned to look up at him, and for a moment the terrified Portuguese princess was gone, replaced by an eighteen-year-old girl who'd just heard her husband complain about his discomfort like any normal person might. Her whisper back was equally conspiratorial:

"You looked like Saint Michael himself. But you also looked like you might faint at any moment during the Gospel reading."

"I nearly did during the homily," Juan admitted quietly, and her suppressed laugh turned into an undignified giggle that she had to forcibly control before they reached the platform.

Dona Beatriz, walking just behind them with the other Portuguese ladies, looked scandalized and delighted in equal measure—scandalized that her princess was giggling on the cathedral steps, delighted that she was happy.

Then they ascended to the platform, and the public masks returned. Juan straightened despite his exhaustion, projecting strength and sacred authority. Isabel's expression smoothed into queenly composure, though the sparkle of amusement remained in her eyes. Together they turned to face the plaza.

The Public Blessing

The platform placed them ten feet above the cathedral plaza, visible to thousands. The crowd's noise was constant—a living thing that rose and fell but never ceased, prayer and celebration and raw enthusiasm mixed together.

Cardinal Capranica stepped forward to the platform's edge, his ceremonial robes brilliant in the midday sun, his crosier raised high. The Archbishop of Toledo stood beside him, arms spread wide. Behind them, the great cathedral doors framed the scene, the Guardian Company arranged with military precision holding the banner and reliquaries aloft.

The legate's voice, trained to carry across vast spaces, somehow cut through the noise:

"FAITHFUL OF CHRIST!"

The crowd began to quiet, thousands shushing each other, desperate to hear. The silence rippled outward from the cathedral in waves until the entire plaza held its breath.

"Behold your King and Queen!" Capranica's Latin was clear, his gestures theatrical. "Joined this day in holy matrimony before God and witnesses! Crowned in the sight of Heaven!"

The roar came back, but Capranica raised his hands for silence again. The crowd obeyed—barely, the noise subsiding to an eager murmur.

"Before you stand the instruments of God's holy purpose! The blessed banner!" He gestured to where the Guardian Company held it aloft, the white silk rippling in the breeze. "The sacred relics of our Lord's True Cross and the blessed Saint James!" The reliquaries caught the sun and threw back golden fire. "And the warrior-king chosen to wield them in righteous war!"

Another roar, quickly suppressed as people strained to hear more.

The Archbishop took over, his Castilian Spanish more comfortable for the common people: "God has blessed this union! God has blessed this crusade! God has blessed Castile with a king who will complete the work of centuries—who will drive the Moor from our sacred soil and reclaim Granada for Christ!"

The response was thunderous. People were crying, praying, shouting. Young men in the crowd were pushing forward, clearly desperate to volunteer. Veterans of previous campaigns stood with tears streaming into grey beards. Women held up children so they could witness this moment.

In the noble viewing areas, the great houses stood in visible approval. Don Íñigo López de Mendoza was nodding slowly, his assessment clear—this theater was masterful, this staging would be remembered. His son Pedro was openly weeping, his hand over his heart where his crusader oath burned. Admiral Enríquez stood with his family, all of them moved despite their naval sophistication.

Cardinal Capranica raised both hands high, his voice reaching its crescendo: "Therefore, in the name of His Holiness Pope Martin V, by the authority vested in me as Papal Legate to Castile, I proclaim to all faithful Christians: BLESSED ARE THOSE WHO TAKE UP THIS SACRED CAUSE! BLESSED ARE THOSE WHO FIGHT BENEATH THIS BANNER! BLESSED ARE THOSE WHO GIVE THEIR LIVES TO COMPLETE THE RECONQUISTA!"

He made the sign of the cross over the entire plaza, his movements large and theatrical. "In nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti!"

"AMEN!" The response came from ten thousand throats at once, a sound like thunder rolling across Toledo.

The Archbishop joined Capranica, both prelates now with hands raised in benediction: "Go forth in the knowledge that God favors this crusade! Go forth knowing that those who serve beneath this banner serve Heaven itself! Go forth and witness the glory of righteous war!"

The crowd erupted. The noise was indescribable—not just cheering but religious ecstasy given voice. People were collapsing to their knees. Others had hands raised toward heaven. Young men were shouting their willingness to fight. Mothers were weeping, whether from joy or fear for their sons it was impossible to say.

Juan stood beside Isabel, letting the moment wash over him. The armor's weight was forgotten in this instant—or rather, it became part of the message. He was suffering for this cause already, before a single battle had been fought. Visible sacrifice. Visible commitment.

Isabel's hand found his, their fingers intertwining despite his gauntlet. She squeezed once, and he returned it. Whatever else this marriage was or wasn't, in this moment they were partners in something larger than themselves.

The Guardian Company began to descend the cathedral steps, moving with ceremonial precision. The four bearing the banner came first, the white silk brilliant against the stone cathedral and blue sky. The two with reliquaries followed, gold and silver gleaming. The remaining crusaders formed an honor guard, their white tabards and red crosses a powerful visual symbol.

They processed through the plaza toward the cleared area where the crusader recruitment would take place. The crowd parted before them, people reaching out to touch the crusaders' horses, to get close to the banner, to be near these sacred objects.

The fifty crusaders formed up in perfect ranks in the cleared space, the banner raised high at their center, the reliquaries positioned on either side. They stood at absolute attention, motionless as statues, a visual representation of discipline and holy purpose.

Fray Hernando stood beside them, his Franciscan robes somehow dignified despite their simplicity. Diego waited with his ledger, ready to record new names. Behind them, several other clergy held additional ledgers—clearly expecting significant numbers of volunteers.

The crowd pressed close to the barriers, held back by city guards. Young men were already shouting their desire to volunteer, pushing forward, desperate to be among the first to take the oath.

Juan and Isabel remained on the platform with the two prelates. From here they could see the entire plaza, the crusader formation, the crowd, the city spreading beyond. Álvaro had positioned himself at the base of the platform steps, ready to coordinate whatever came next.

Cardinal Capranica turned to Juan, speaking quietly beneath the crowd noise: "Your Majesty, the stage is set. When you are ready, address them. Call for volunteers. Those who wish to take the crusader oath should come forward for evaluation by Fray Hernando and the Guardian Company. Let them see that service beneath this banner is both sacred privilege and serious commitment."

The legate paused, something like respect in his usually bureaucratic face. "You have created something extraordinary here, Your Majesty. Use it well."

The sun was high overhead now, the day warming, the plaza packed with humanity waiting for the next act in this drama.

The Call to Arms

Juan's voice rang across the plaza, trained for command but now carrying something more—conviction, faith, the weight of history itself.

"People of Castile! Fellow Christians!"

The crowd stilled instantly, every eye fixed on the white-armored figure on the platform.

"Today we start something that has been centuries in the making. Something that has been coming, something inevitable. All of Iberia shall be Christian and Islamic rule shall be thrown into the sea!"

The roar came back like a wave breaking, but Juan raised his gauntleted hand and they quieted again, desperate to hear every word.

"We stand at the beginning of a long task, for it will take many years. We will all of us be tested. When we stand watch alone on a cold night. When we sit huddled at a fire in a siege that seems to go on forever. When we return home after a long season of brutal fighting and toil and glory seems so far away—think back at this moment. Think of why we are doing this and keep your eye on the prize."

The crowd was utterly silent now. This wasn't the usual royal rhetoric promising easy victory and quick glory. This was honesty. This was a king who understood what he was asking.

"We all contribute in our own way. Monks pray, the rich donate, some just help through their labor. And some may feel the sacred call to join the crusade itself."

Juan gestured toward where the Guardian Company stood with the banner raised high, white silk rippling in the breeze, reliquaries gleaming.

"If you feel that call. If you feel the urge to be a part of this sacred invincible army, you can join me and my brothers in the crusade. We accept all regardless of station. Victory in Granada means rewards according to your station—lands in Granada. Join if you hear the call and I will lead you to victory."

His right hand moved to the hilt of his father's sword—Non Nobis Domine etched along its blade. The steel sang as he drew it, the sound cutting through the silence. He raised it high, the blade catching the sun and throwing light across the plaza.

"NON NOBIS DOMINE!"

The response was instantaneous and overwhelming.

"NON NOBIS DOMINE!" Ten thousand voices screaming the Latin phrase—"Not unto us, O Lord!" The cry of the Templars, the prayer of righteous warriors, now the battle cry of this new crusade.

Young men surged toward the barriers. The city guards struggled to hold the lines as dozens—then scores—pressed forward, shouting their desire to volunteer. Some were weeping as they pushed through the crowd. Others had expressions of almost religious ecstasy.

"I'LL FIGHT! TAKE ME!"
"FOR CHRIST AND CASTILE!"
"MY FATHER FELL AT ANTEQUERA—LET ME FINISH IT!"
"TAKE MY OATH! TAKE MY OATH!"

Veterans in the crowd stood with tears streaming down their weathered faces, their hands pressed to their hearts. Women wept openly—some in pride, others in fear, most in both. Monks and clergy were chanting prayers, their voices rising beneath the chaos.

In the noble viewing areas, the response was equally powerful though more controlled. Young nobles were on their feet, hands on sword hilts, clearly desperate to prove themselves worthy. Don Pedro González de Mendoza had both hands gripping the railing of his family's stand, his face shining with purpose. Even older nobles looked moved—men who'd seen war and knew its cost, but who recognized this moment's significance.

The Guardian Company remained motionless, their discipline absolute, but every man's face showed emotion—pride, joy, determination. They were witnessing their brotherhood about to grow, their sacred mission gaining the warriors it needed.

Fray Hernando stepped forward, raising his hands for order. His voice, surprisingly powerful for a Franciscan friar, cut through the noise: "ALL WHO WOULD TAKE THE CRUSADER'S OATH—FORM LINES! YOU WILL BE EVALUATED FOR FITNESS OF BODY AND PURITY OF PURPOSE! THIS IS NOT A TAVERN BRAWL BUT A HOLY WAR! ORDER! MAINTAIN ORDER!"

Diego and the other clerks moved forward with their ledgers, ready to begin the lengthy process of recording names, evaluating candidates, administering oaths. City guards worked to create orderly lines from the chaos of volunteers.

Álvaro appeared at the base of the platform steps, looking up at Juan with an expression of mingled awe and calculation. "Your Majesty," he called up, "the recruitment will take hours. Perhaps the tour of the city should proceed? Let the people see their king and queen, let the volunteers come to the banner in organized fashion?"

He paused, then added more quietly: "And perhaps Your Majesty would appreciate removing that armor in a more private setting?"

Behind Juan, Cardinal Capranica was nodding in approval at the chaos below. "Extraordinary, Your Majesty. Absolutely extraordinary. I have seen papal processions in Rome, coronations of kings, but this..." He shook his head. "This is the power of genuine faith wedded to political theater. Well done."

The Archbishop of Toledo added his own thoughts: "The recruitment should continue throughout the afternoon. By evening, we may have hundreds of new volunteers. When they see the standards you've set with the Guardian Company, the quality of men this crusade attracts..."

Isabel stood beside Juan, still holding his hand, her crown balanced perfectly on her head now. She looked up at him with an expression that mixed admiration and concern. "You should rest," she said quietly. "You've been in that armor for four hours."

The plaza continued its controlled chaos below—volunteers pressing forward, the Guardian Company holding position, clergy moving among the crowd blessing those who came forward, and over it all the blessed banner rippling in the breeze.

The sun was past its zenith now, early afternoon warmth settling over Toledo. The tour of the city awaited—a chance to be seen by thousands more, to spread the word throughout the kingdom's greatest city. And then, this evening, the dinner with the nobles where the taxation would be formally announced and the machinery of war would be set fully in motion.
