The Royal Tour

Juan raised his sword high one final time, the blade catching the sun, then sheathed it with a practiced motion. He turned to Isabel and together they waved to the plaza—she with the natural grace of Portuguese royalty, he in the slightly stiff movements of a man encased in plate armor for four hours.

The crowd's response was another roar of approval. Thousands of hands waved back, white cloths and colored scarves creating a sea of motion across the plaza.

They descended from the platform carefully. For Isabel it was merely a matter of managing her train with her ladies' help. For Juan, each step down required deliberate attention—the armor's weight combined with fatigue making balance more precarious. But he managed it without stumbling, maintaining the image of the warrior-king even as his legs trembled with exhaustion.

The white destrier waited where it had been held throughout the ceremony, still caparisoned in pure white, still bearing the tall poles with their streaming banners. A mounting block had been positioned beside it—necessary now, after four hours of standing and sitting in full plate. Juan's legs were not entirely reliable.

He placed his gauntleted hand on the saddle and pulled himself up. The movement was harder than it had been this morning—muscles fatigued, armor seeming heavier, every joint protesting. But he made it into the saddle, settling with the practiced skill of someone who'd ridden in armor many times before, even if never for this long.

The banners attached to his saddle caught the breeze immediately, streaming backward like white wings. The effect remained spectacular even though Juan could barely appreciate it through his exhaustion and discomfort.

Isabel's palfrey was brought forward—a gentle grey mare with a ladies' side-saddle, caparisoned in white and gold. Her Portuguese ladies helped her mount with efficient grace, arranging her gown and train perfectly. The crown remained on her head, and she balanced it naturally now, having worn it for over an hour.

Álvaro mounted his black destrier, positioning himself at Juan's right hand once again. Behind them, the royal household guard formed up. The Guardian Company—minus the volunteers who would remain at the cathedral to process recruits throughout the afternoon—took positions around the royal couple.

Don Rodrigo de Villalobos appeared with the planned route on a small parchment, consulting with the city watch captain about the streets. "Your Majesty, we'll proceed through the commercial districts first—the Calle Mayor, past the great market, through the artisan quarters. Then to the Jewish quarter where the community has prepared an address of loyalty. Then through the northern residential districts where the lesser nobility have their houses. Perhaps two hours total, allowing for stops and addresses. The people have been waiting all day to see you."

The procession formed up. The banner-bearers took the lead, the white silk brilliant in the afternoon sun. Then Juan and Isabel, side by side, king and queen. Then the nobility in order of precedence—Don Íñigo López de Mendoza and his son Pedro prominent among them, Admiral Enríquez and his family, the Masters of the Military Orders who had attended, representatives of every great house.

The city gates leading out of the cathedral district stood open. Beyond them, the streets of Toledo waited—packed with humanity that had been there since dawn, that had heard the Mass echoing from the cathedral, that had seen the banner raised and heard the king's call to crusade.

The procession moved forward at a ceremonial walk. As they passed through the gates, the noise began again—that overwhelming wall of sound that was part celebration, part prayer, part something beyond words.

Through the Streets of Toledo

The route took them down from the cathedral heights into the heart of Toledo's commercial district. The Calle Mayor—the city's main street—had been decorated with banners and garlands. Every balcony was packed with people. Every window held faces. The street itself was lined ten deep on both sides despite the barriers.

As Juan rode past in his white armor with banners streaming, the response was immediate and intense. People fell to their knees. Others reached out as if they could touch him from distance. Children on shoulders pointed and shouted. Women threw flowers—white roses, carnations, lilies—creating a carpet of petals on the cobblestones.

"LONG LIVE THE KING!"
"QUEEN ISABEL! BLESSED BE!"
"SAINT MICHAEL RIDES AMONG US!"
"FOR THE CRUSADE! FOR CHRIST!"

The shouts came from every direction, overlapping into a cacophony of devotion. Juan waved, turning in his saddle to acknowledge different sections of the crowd despite the armor's constraints and his body's fatigue. Beside him, Isabel waved with both hands, her face showing wonder at the reception.

Through the great market square—normally packed with stalls and merchants but cleared today for the procession. The guild masters stood in organized groups, their ceremonial robes marking their crafts. The butchers' guild, the cloth merchants, the metalworkers, the bakers—each group bowing as the procession passed.

The master of the metalworkers' guild stepped forward, holding up a small chest. "Your Majesty! Our guild donates fifty florins to the crusade and pledges our craft to equip your warriors!"

Others followed—the cloth merchants pledging banners and tabards, the leatherworkers offering to make saddles and harness at cost, the armorer's guild promising priority service. Each pledge was recorded by clerks riding among the procession, but the offers came faster than they could write.

Into the artisan quarters where the workshops lined narrow streets. The smiths had arranged an honor guard of their apprentices, all holding hammers high in salute. The sound of metal on metal rang out as the procession passed—a rhythmic clanging that was both martial and celebratory.

An elderly carpenter stood at his workshop door, tears streaming down his face. "My grandson!" he shouted. "He's at the cathedral now, taking the oath! Bless him, Your Majesty! Bless him!"

Juan raised his hand in acknowledgment, and the old man collapsed to his knees, openly weeping.

The Jewish quarter lay in the eastern section of the city, its streets narrower, its buildings packed closer. The community had prepared for this moment—the rabbi and community leaders stood in ceremonial dress at the quarter's main plaza, a presentation prepared.

The rabbi stepped forward, his Hebrew accented Spanish careful and formal: "Your Majesty, Queen Isabel, the Jewish community of Toledo pledges its loyalty and support. We offer ten thousand maravedís to the crusade treasury and our prayers for your success."

It was a carefully calculated pledge—enough to show loyalty without being so large as to attract resentment or accusations of excessive wealth. The rabbi knew the delicate position his people occupied.

Juan acknowledged the gift with a nod, and the Jewish community bowed deeply as the procession continued. In the narrow streets, faces watched from windows—cautious, hopeful, aware that crusading fervor could sometimes turn against non-Christians even within Christian kingdoms.

Through the northern residential districts where lesser nobility and wealthy merchants had their houses. These families stood at their doorways in their finest clothing, their household servants arranged behind them. Each bowed as the procession passed, and many pledged support—men for the levies, money for the treasury, supplies for the armies.

A widow in black stepped into the street, held back from approaching closer by guards but near enough to be heard. "Your Majesty! My husband fell at Antequera! My son is at the cathedral taking the oath! Finish the work! Finish it so no more widows weep!"

Her voice cracked on the last words, and Isabel's face showed emotion—genuine sympathy for this woman's loss. She reached into a small purse at her belt and gestured to a guard, who took coins to the widow. A small gesture, but noted by the crowd nearby.

The sun was lowering now, mid-afternoon sliding toward evening. The tour had taken nearly two hours of constant riding, constant waving, constant public presence. Juan's entire body was screaming for relief. The armor that had seemed merely uncomfortable during the Mass was now approaching torture. Sweat soaked the padding beneath the steel. His shoulders burned. His thighs cramped. His back felt like it might break.

But he maintained the image—upright, strong, waving to the crowds. The angel of war could not show weakness.

Isabel rode beside him, and occasionally their eyes would meet. She could see his exhaustion, could see him struggling, but she said nothing—simply being present, her solidarity a form of support.

At last, the procession turned back toward the Alcázar. The palace came into view, its walls rising above the city, its gates standing open. The plaza before it was packed, but the guards had maintained a clear path.

One final surge of cheering as the people recognized the procession was returning. One final wave of religious fervor and patriotic enthusiasm. Then they were passing through the gates into the relative quiet of the palace courtyard.

The Relief of Disarming

The moment the gates closed behind them, cutting off the crowd's noise to a distant murmur, Juan felt his entire body sag slightly in the saddle. The public performance was over. Privacy at last.

Servants rushed forward. Master Gonzalo appeared from somewhere, his apprentices with him—they had remained at the palace, ready for this moment.

Juan practically fell from the saddle, his legs barely holding him as he dismounted. Two grooms steadied him, and he had to stand still for a moment, simply keeping his balance as the blood returned to cramped muscles.

"Your Majesty," Master Gonzalo said urgently, "let us get you out of this. Quickly now, before you collapse."

They moved to the great hall where he'd armed that morning—it felt like a lifetime ago. Isabel followed with her ladies, then tactfully dismissed them to give Juan privacy for the disarming. Only she remained, watching with concern as the process began.

The gauntlets came off first—Juan pulled them free himself, desperate to feel air on his hands. Then the helpers began working on straps and buckles. The arm harness came apart piece by piece. The breastplate was lifted away, and Juan took the first full breath he'd had in over four hours, his chest expanding without restriction.

"Madre de Dios," he breathed, and despite the blasphemy Isabel didn't correct him—she understood.

The back plate, the gorget, the leg harness—each piece removed revealed padding soaked through with sweat. Juan's under-clothing was drenched, his hair plastered to his head. When the last piece came off and he stood in just the soaked arming doublet, he looked like he'd been swimming.

He sat heavily in a chair, not caring about dignity, and one of Master Gonzalo's apprentices knelt to remove his boots and the padded shoes beneath. His feet were swollen, red, marked with pressure points from the armor's weight transmitted through the leg harness.

"Water," Juan managed. "For the love of God, water."

A servant rushed forward with a pitcher and cup. Juan drank deeply, the lukewarm water the finest thing he'd ever tasted.

Isabel approached, her crown still balanced on her head—she'd worn it so long now she'd forgotten about it. She knelt beside his chair, propriety forgotten, and took his hand. "You did it. You were magnificent."

Friends, fellow nobles, Christians of Castille, my brothers in faith,


We started today the reconquista. We have all taken vows and oaths, and now is a moment where I announce the practical aspects of the crusade and the taxation the papal bull mentioned should be levied to finance the campain.


There will be a 5% tax on revenue on all noble estates and 10% on all chruch revenues. I have worked together with the vatican and it's legate to ensure these taxes are fair and just. To ensure correct estimates of actual revenue, we will assess the revenues. It will be performed by both crown and vatican assessors. They will visit your estates and I expect everyone's cooperation so no one will have the feeling to pay more than his neighbour.


There is however an exemption I want to introduce to this tax in order to keep it just and to make sure smaller estates are not unjustly squeezed. Every noble who serves in the crusade personally will be excempt from paying 2000 maravedis for that year. This ensures these taxes are both fair and just, something I think is very important.


And finally, I will make full use of the power vested in me by the bull to grant me full command and the ability to raise noble levies for the coming campain. These will be supported by their noble lords, but the crown will provide supplies like food ect. I require you to fight as per our ancient noble contract. Be ready to be called upon for I will do so in the coming year.


But now lets talk of rewards. When we take Grenada, the lands will of course be divided under those who have fought the most and the hardest first. I will first give lands to the vowed crusaders, then to the nobles of the reals according to their contribution. When we have secured these lands, we not only free ourselves from raids on lands, but we also secire the sea routes. We can finally start to secure our ports and start building our trade fleets in the image of Portugal. Even more riches await us.


A toast to a successful crusade and future glories!


I raise my glass and toast.

The Taxation Announcement

Juan stood, and the hall fell into absolute silence. Every noble, every cleric, every merchant held their breath. This was the moment that would determine how deeply this crusade would reach into their purses.

His voice carried clearly across the great hall, measured and authoritative. He laid out the terms methodically—the 5% on noble estates, the 10% on church revenues, the assessment teams, the cooperation expected. Then the exemption for personal service, and finally the promise of Granada's lands for those who fought.

When he raised his glass in toast, there was a moment—just a heartbeat—of hesitation.

Then Cardinal Capranica rose, his cup raised high. "TO THE CRUSADE!"

The Archbishop of Toledo followed immediately. "TO VICTORY IN GRANADA!"

The hall erupted. Two hundred nobles and clergy rose as one, cups raised, the response thunderous: "TO THE CRUSADE! TO VICTORY! TO CASTILE!"

But the response was more complex than simple enthusiasm. Juan could see it in the faces, in the body language, in the speed or reluctance with which different nobles rose.

The Committed Houses:

Don Íñigo López de Mendoza was on his feet instantly, his cup high, his voice booming approval. His son Pedro beside him was practically glowing—having taken the crusader oath that morning, his house would benefit from both the exemption and future land grants. "WELL SPOKEN, YOUR MAJESTY! FAIR AND JUST!"

Admiral Enríquez stood with military precision, his naval expertise already pledged. The exemption meant little to him—he'd serve regardless—but the promise of secured sea routes and trade had his attention. His expression showed calculation mixed with approval.

Don Luis de Guzmán, Master of Santiago, raised his cup with genuine enthusiasm. The Military Orders paid the church tax anyway, but the promise of lands in Granada was attractive, and his Order was fully committed. "THE SANTIAGO RIDES WITH YOU, YOUR MAJESTY!"

The Calculating Nobility:

Many of the great houses rose and toasted but with visible reservation. They understood the mathematics—5% of their revenues was substantial, even with the 2,000 maravedí exemption for personal service. The assessment teams meant they couldn't simply lie about their wealth.

But they also understood the political reality. The overwhelming response to the wedding procession, the religious fervor in the streets, the papal backing—this crusade had momentum that made opposition dangerous. Better to comply and seek advantage than resist and be labeled unpatriotic or impious.

A middle-aged lord from the Stúñiga family stood with his cup raised, his face showing careful neutrality. "To the crusade," he said, loud enough to be heard but without enthusiasm.

The Manrique clan—Rodrigo's relatives—rose in solid support, their family honor tied to their kinsman's command of the western army. But their faces showed the calculation: how much would this cost versus how much could they gain?

The Reluctant Compliance:

Some houses rose more slowly. Faces showing poorly concealed dismay at the taxation announcement, but the social pressure too great to remain seated. A few older lords who remembered previous failed campaigns looked skeptical about the promises of land and riches.

One elderly grandee—Don García de Ayala, known for his wealth and his parsimony—stood with his cup raised but his lips pressed thin. He would pay because he had to, but he clearly wasn't happy about it.

Several lesser nobles were doing rapid mental calculations, trying to figure out whether the 2,000 maravedí exemption was worth personally serving in a dangerous military campaign. Some would conclude yes, eager for adventure or land. Others would pay the tax and stay home.

The Church Response:

The Archbishop of Toledo's enthusiastic support was genuine—he understood that 10% church taxation was the papal bull's explicit authorization and couldn't be contested. Better to embrace it enthusiastically than appear to resist Rome's will.

Other clergy in attendance showed more mixed reactions. Some monasteries and religious houses were wealthy; 10% would hurt. But Cardinal Capranica's presence made resistance impossible. They rose and toasted with varying degrees of conviction.

The Foreign Observers:

The Portuguese ambassador stood with obvious satisfaction—his princess was now queen, the alliance sealed, and Portugal stood to benefit from Castile's crusade without bearing its costs. He toasted enthusiastically.

The Aragonese observer was more reserved, calculating what this meant for the balance of power in Iberia. A successful Castilian conquest of Granada would make Juan's kingdom dominant. But he toasted politely, aware that openly showing concern would be impolitic.

The Aftermath of the Toast

As everyone drank and sat back down, the hall erupted into conversation. The formal announcement was done; now came the private processing, the calculations, the political maneuvering.

Álvaro remained standing, his voice cutting through the growing noise: "Assessment teams will begin deployment in the spring. All noble houses will receive formal notice before assessors arrive. The oversight committee—His Majesty, Cardinal Capranica, and the Archbishop—will review all assessments for fairness. Appeals may be made to the committee directly."

This addition seemed to ease some tensions. The promise of oversight and appeals suggested the process wouldn't be arbitrary, that there would be recourse against unfair assessment.

Don Íñigo López de Mendoza rose again, his voice carrying: "Your Majesty, the House of Mendoza pledges full cooperation with the assessment and reaffirms our commitment of eighteen hundred men to the crusade!" It was a public declaration of support designed to set an example for other houses.

Others followed, competing to show loyalty:

"The Enríquez family pledges cooperation and naval expertise!"

"House Manrique stands ready to serve!"

"The Guzmán clan offers full support!"

Each declaration built momentum, creating social pressure on those who might otherwise resist. To remain silent now would mark a house as potentially disloyal or impious.

Cardinal Capranica stood, raising his hands for attention. "His Majesty has demonstrated both the authority granted by His Holiness and the wisdom to use it justly. The exemption for personal service shows understanding of noble sacrifice. The joint assessment ensures fairness. The promise of Granada's lands rewards the faithful. This is how a Christian king prosecutes holy war."

The papal legate's endorsement carried enormous weight. Any house considering resistance now faced not just the king but Rome itself.

The dessert courses began arriving—elaborate confections, fruits preserved in honey, sweetened wines. The formal business was concluded; the remainder of the evening would be celebration and private conversations.

Nobles began moving between tables, forming small groups to discuss implications. Some approached the high table to speak with Juan directly, others clustered around Álvaro or Cardinal Capranica seeking clarification on specific points.

Don García de Ayala, the elderly grandee who'd looked so unhappy, approached the high table. He bowed stiffly. "Your Majesty, the House of Ayala will of course comply with the assessment. However, I must note that my estates have suffered from poor harvests these past two years. I trust the assessors will take such factors into account when calculating revenue?"

It was phrased as a request but carried an edge—a warning that he would fight any assessment he deemed unfair.

Near the lower tables, younger nobles were clustered in excited conversation—clearly discussing whether to take crusader oaths themselves to gain the exemption and the promise of land. The 2,000 maravedí exemption had created exactly the incentive Juan intended: encouraging personal service while maintaining revenue.

A group of clergy gathered around the Archbishop, their conversation too quiet to overhear but their expressions showing concern. Ten percent of church revenues was substantial, and many religious houses operated on tight margins already.

Isabel sat beside Juan, observing it all with intelligent eyes. She leaned close, her voice quiet: "You've given them no room to refuse without looking like they oppose the crusade itself. Clever. But some of them..." she gestured subtly toward Don García and a few others, "will make the assessments difficult."

The evening continued. More wine flowed. Musicians played. Nobles moved between tables in complex social dances of alliance and rivalry. Through it all, the underlying calculation: how much would this cost, how much could be gained, and was resistance possible or even wise?

By the time the final courses were cleared and nobles began taking their leave—bowing to the king and queen, offering final congratulations on the marriage—the consensus seemed clear: the taxation would proceed. Some enthusiastically, some grudgingly, but it would proceed.

Álvaro approached the high table as the crowd thinned. "Your Majesty, that went as well as could be hoped. A few will resist the assessments, try to hide wealth or claim poverty, but the oversight structure will handle it. The exemption for personal service was brilliant—it's already working. I've had six nobles approach me tonight about taking crusader oaths specifically to reduce their tax burden."

He paused, a slight smile. "Of course, once they take the oath and serve in the campaign, whether they saved two thousand maravedís becomes rather academic. They'll be crusaders regardless of their original motivation."

Cardinal Capranica joined them, his usually stern face showing something like approval. "Well executed, Your Majesty. The assessment program will be rigorous but fair. Those who cooperate will find the process reasonable. Those who resist..." he shrugged, "will learn that Rome's patience has limits."

The great hall was nearly empty now, servants beginning to clear the remains of the feast. The wedding day—begun before dawn with the armoring, continuing through the overwhelming procession, the three-hour Mass, the tour of Toledo, and now this formal dinner—was finally ending.

Isabel looked exhausted but satisfied. The crown was gone from her head, handed off to attendants hours ago. Her crimson gown was slightly rumpled. But she held herself with dignity, every inch a queen despite being only eighteen and in a foreign kingdom.

The day had achieved everything intended: the marriage sealed, the alliance formalized, the crusade proclaimed, the taxation announced, the nobles committed or at least compliant. Tomorrow the real work would begin—assessment teams deployed, levies mustered, supplies procured, armies assembled.

But tonight, the foundation was laid.
